columns.text: In this exercise, we will discuss the characteristics of zero-coupon bonds. We'll also analyze two different methods of interest deduction and decide which one is best for the zero-coupon bond given in the exercise text. Let's get started!

Let's start by explaining the key terms of this exercise. A bond that pays out no coupons is called a zero-coupon bond. As a result, zero-coupon bonds typically trade at a discount, meaning investors make money when they redeem them for face value at maturity. Despite not paying out any interest, a zero-coupon bond issuer deducts interest from its taxes every year. In the same way, the owner must pay taxes on interest accrued every year, even though the owner does not receive any interest. There are two methods for calculating the interest - the straight-line method and the IRS amortization method . In the past, interest deductions were calculated using a straight-line method . To calculate the interest deduction using the straight-line method, we can divide the total interest accrued over a period by the number of years in that period. That way, we'll get an average interest deduction per year. The IRS amortization method is the method currently proposed by the tax laws. It says that we can determine the implicit interest by amortizing the loan. To do this, we should calculate the bond price change for each year. The difference in the bond's price for the year represents the interest deduction.

Recall the formula for calculating the bond's price: $$\text{Bond Price} = \text{Future Coupon Payments} + \text{Par value at maturity}$$ Given that zero-coupon bonds don't pay out coupon payments, their price can be calculated as: $$\text{Bond Price} = \text{Par value at maturity}$$

We can calculate the face value of the bond at maturity by using the following calculation:

$$\text{Par Value At Maturity} = \frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^t} $$

Where:

- $\text{FV}$ - Face value

- $\text{YTM}$ - Yield to maturity
 
- $\text{t}$ - Number of compounding periods

Considering that, in the case of zero-coupon bonds, the bond's price equals the face value at maturity, we calculate the zero-coupon bond's price as:


$$\text{Bond Price} =  \frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^t}\tag{1}$$

Where:

- $\text{FV}$ - Face value

- $\text{YTM}$ - Yield to maturity
 
- $\text{t}$ - Number of compounding periods

Part a.) In this part of the exercise, we need to calculate the bond price at issuance. We are given the following information on our zero-coupon bond: 1. The face value is assumed at $1,000. 2. Considering that the time to maturity is 25 years, the number of compounding periods will be 50 because the bond pays out the coupons semiannually. 3. The annual yield to maturity is 5.8%.

If the annual yield to maturity is 5.8%, then the semiannual yield to maturity will be 2.9% (5.8% divided by 2).

By plugging the given values into Eq. $(1)$, we get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Bond Price} &=\frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^t} \\[15pt] 
&= \frac{\$1,000}{(1+ 2.9\%)^{50}} \\[15pt] 
&= \$239.459
\end{aligned}$$

Part b.) Next, we'll examine the interest deduction using the IRS amortization method . According to the IRS, we should calculate the interest deduction yearly. In other words, for every year left until maturity, we need to calculate the interest deduction for that year. For example, considering our bond has 25 years until maturity, the account would need to calculate the interest deduction for each of these years separately. Hence, the interest deduction will fluctuate every year. Recall that interest reduction using IRS amortization method is calculated as: $$\text{Interest Deduction} = \text{Bond Price}_\text{start} - \text{Bond Price}_\text{end}\tag{2}$$

We first need to find the interest deduction one year from issuance.

The bond price at issuance is our starting value:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Bond Price}_\text{ 25} = \$239.459
\end{aligned}$$

 
 
One year from issuance, the time to maturity is 24 years, and the number of compounding periods is 48. By plugging in the values into Eq.$(1)$, we get the bond price at one year from issuance:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Bond Price}_\text{ 24} &=\frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^t} \\[15pt] 
&= \frac{\$1,000}{(1+ 2.9\%)^{48}} \\[15pt] 
&= \$253.549
\end{aligned}$$

Now, let's input the values into Eq.$(2)$ to calculate the interest deduction for the year after the bond's issuance:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Interest Deduction} &= \text{Bond Price}_\text{25} - \text{Bond Price}_\text{24} \\[10pt]
&= \$239.459 - \$253.549 \\[10pt]
&= -\$14.09

\end{aligned}$$

Similarly, we'll calculate the interest deduction when there is one year left until maturity.
 
 
Since there's only one year left until maturity, the number of compounding periods will be 2. By plugging in the values into Eq.$(1)$, we get the bond price one year away from maturity. This value is our starting price:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Bond Price}_\text{1} &=\frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^t} \\[15pt] 
&= \frac{\$1,000}{(1+ 2.9\%)^{2}} \\[15pt] 
&= \$944.428
\end{aligned}$$


The ending value is equal to the face value because the bond matures at the end of the year we calculate the interest deduction. 

Hence, it will have a price of $1,000:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Bond Price}_\text{0} = \$1,000
\end{aligned}$$

Now, let's input the values into Eq.$(2)$ to calculate the interest deduction:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Interest Deduction} &= \text{Bond Price}_\text{1} - \text{Bond Price}_\text{0} \\[10pt]
&= \$944.428 - \$1,0000\\[10pt]
&= -\$55.572
\end{aligned}$$

Part c.) Now, we'll calculate the interest deduction by using the straight-line method . We can use the following equation to calculate the interest deduction by using the straight-line method : $$\text{Interest Deduction} = \dfrac{\text{Bond Issue Price} - \text{Face Value}}{\text{Bond Term In Years}} \tag{3}$$

By plugging in the values into Eq, $(3)$, we get the following interest deduction:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Interest Deduction} &= \dfrac{\$1,000 - \$239.459}{25} \\[10pt]
&= \$30.42164
\end{aligned}$$

Part D.) We'll start by recollecting all the resulting interest deductions calculated by the two methods and putting them into the table below: | Year| Beginning Value | Ending Value | Implicit Interest Expense | Straight Line Interest Expense | |--|--|--|--|--| | $1$ | $\$239.459$ | $\$253.549$ | $\$14.09$ | $\$30.42164$ | | $25$ | $\$944.428$| $\$1,000$ | $\$55.572$ | $\$30.42164$ | As we can see from the table, the interest deduction using the straight-line method is larger in the first years when compared to the interest deduction using current IRS rules. Hence, the company might prefer the straight-line method to make the zero-coupon bond more attractive to investors.

Let's recap what we have learned in this exercise! First, we explained the key terms of the exercise - the zero-coupon bond and two different methods for calculating interest deductions. Then we calculated the interest deductions for the zero-coupon bond given in the exercise text, first using the IRS amortization method and then the straight-line method. Finally, in the last step, we examined how the resulting interest deductions compare. Our research shows that **companies might prefer the straight-line method.**
